repnme.cdata!:
Willingness to charge and willingness to
            pay : China Rural Water Supply and Sanitation Program

abstracts.cdata!:
In 1985, the World Bank started its
            assistance to the Rural Water Supply and Sanitation (RWS) in
            China, which was a high priority for the Government. The RWS
            program consisted of four successive projects (Rural Water
            Supply Project, National Rural Supply Project, National
            Water Supply and Sanitation Project, and Forth Rural Water
            and Sanitation Project) that lasted over the last 17 years.
            The total World Bank investment in these four projects was
            US$628 million. The program succeeded at serving about 25
            million people in 18 provinces and developed a very
            effective cost recovery policy where the users finance up to
            75 percent of the capital investment as well as the full
            operation and maintenance (O&M) cost. With the World
            Bank assistance, the RWS programs were designed to increase
            rural access to safe drinking water and improved sanitation.
            The first project was not specifically targeted at the poor
            or based completely in rural areas, but both these policies
            changed in succeeding projects. Within the selected
            counties, denser areas were chosen to make the cost of
            supplying piped water economically viable, and within the
            selected villages, the network aimed to cover all economic
            sections of the community. For the more remote and less
            densely populated areas of the project provinces, the
            approach was to provide hand pumps, rainwater collection
            systems and small tube wells.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Review of the Bank's
            assistance to the urban water supply and wastewater sector

abstracts.cdata!:
This sector assistance review not only
            assesses the outcome, sustainability, and institutional
            development of World Bank to the urban water supply and
            wastewater sector, but also tracks the impact of assistance
            in financing reform, regulatory reforms including tariff
            regulation, institutional reforms, and reforms to promote
            private service provision. OED rates the outcome of the
            Bank's assistance, moderately satisfactory, with
            sustainability likely because of strong government support.
            Institutional development impact is rated modest. Both Bank
            and Borrower performances are considered satisfactory. The
            report makes these six recommendations: 1) Demand management
            should always precede supply increases and investments in
            wastewater treatment. 2) Set tariffs to reflect future total
            costs and create incentives for billing and collecting those
            higher tariffs. 3) Build and support autonomous utilities.
            4) Enhance the level of self-financing. 5) Mitigate risk and
            improve efficiency through regulation. 6) Enable greater
            private sector participation.

18151477.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Rural Water Supply
            Project are to build water supply facilities and to develop
            and strengthen systems, institutions and technology for the
            implementation of China's rural water supply program.
            The project will provide safe drinking water to some six
            million people in 4,650 villages of 25 counties located in
            the provinces of Liaoning, Shaanxi, Sichuan and Zhejiang and
            the municipality of Beijing.  The types of water systems
            range from handpumps and rainwater storage tanks to pumped
            and piped systems (including some with treatment) with
            standpipes or house connections, dependent upon
            environmental and economic conditions.  The institutional
            component of the project includes:  (i) the development of
            management and monitoring systems as well as regulations for
            revolving funds, construction and operations.  This
            component further involves; (ii) the preparation of design,
            construction and operation manuals; and (iii) a training
            program for trainers, planners, engineers, technicians and
            operators at the national, provincial, county and village levels.
